newsitem.title: CHINA: PRESS DIGEST - Chinese newspapers - Sept 9.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Chinese newspapers - Sept 9.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Chinese political and business stories in leading newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Beijing. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy. Telephone: (8610) 6532-1921. Fax: (8610) 6532-4978.
China's new mineral resources law is to take effect on January 1, 1997.
Qiao Shi, Chairman of National People's Congress, or parliament, praised Fiji for its "one China" stance and said he hoped China could increase cooperation with South Pacific nations.
A commentary praised Mao Zedong, who died 20 years ago today, and current paramount leader Deng Xiaoping for their service to the people.
The Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation has protested against a U.S. reduction of import quotas for Chinese textiles.
China said the U.S. missile attacks on Iraq were another example of U.S. hegemonism and had infringed on Iraq's sovereignty and territorial integrity.
Experts have urged adjustment in blue-chip shares in the Shanghai stock exchange's new index.
China analysts are urging commercial property developers to lower prices to make housing affordable to wage-earners.
The State Commission for Economic Restructuring says there will be a further overhaul of state firms.
Sluggish sales were a major factor contributing to the poor performance of listed firms in the first half.
Northwestern Xinjiang region's oil production capacity is to hit 17 million tonnes in 1996, up from 15 million tonnes in 1995.
Steel production capacity of Baoshan Iron and Steel Corp to reach 11 million tonnes a year after completion of third phase of expansion project in December.
China should take greater steps to combat fires in top coal mines that burn out 200,000 to 300,000 tonnes of coal a year.
